snippet: Tim Burton’s “Dark Shadows,” opening Friday, was born of his love of the television series of the same name, from Dan Curtis, that ran in the late 1960s.
abstract: Director Tim Burton's latest movie Dark Shadows is based on the 1960s soap opera of the same name, which he watched avidly as a child. Photos (M)
lead_paragraph: IT was ''Satan's favorite TV show,'' according to a religious tract of the time. Tim Burton, 8 years old when the Gothic daytime soap opera ''Dark Shadows'' came into the world and not quite 13 when it breathed its last, was clearly untroubled that his viewing preferences were similar to those of the Prince of Darkness. ''I should probably have been doing homework or playing sports after school instead of watching 'Dark Shadows,' '' he said. ''But seeing that show every afternoon, at home, in Burbank, it just doesn't get much weirder than that.'' And for Mr. Burton, the director of ''Edward Scissorhands,'' ''Sleepy Hollow,'' and now a splashy silver-screen ''Dark Shadows'' (opening Friday), ''weird'' is a term of the very highest praise.

headline.main: The Vampire Who Came Out In the Afternoon
